Posts.Content: Mar 27, 2012 09:19AM Baileybump wrote: So as they were shifting me around and I was on the table, all of a sudden I was overcome by emotions.  My tech said, "what's that for?"  I don't know!  And here I sit with tears again.  I think it's because I haven't been doing anything for about 6 weeks, since chemo. . . nothing "cancer" related.  Now I'm a patient again.  :-(  Tears rolled through the entire treatment . . and then on the way home. . . and then when my DH came home  I guess it was time for a cleansing.  I also allow myself ti sit and question my treatment decisions and know that I shouldn't.  There was a woman in the waiting area who talked about herself.  She was 0.9 cm, stage 1, grade 2, low oncotype and opted to have BMX and hysterectomy.  So I immediately wonder if I made the right decision by having the lumpectomy/radiation.  Ugh.  Then another woman said she started Tomoxifen right after surgery. . . and I haven't started it yet  So naturally I worry about that, too.  I don't know if she had chemo, though.  The BMX lady did not have chemo, but IS having radiation because it was close to her chest wall.  Rachel - Hugs to you as you squabble with your BF.  We've all got your back and understand what you're feeling.  And the surrounding people are so out of touch.  I was recently telling my mom that I haven't had a period since December and that it's common.  To which she replies, "don't forget, the radiation doctor said not to get pregnant."  Really?  I've opted not to have children (I'm 44).  My response was, "can't get pregnant without . . . Breast cancer treatment has a way of making you feel a lot ‘less sexy', Mom."   Ugh. Karmil - Hoping today went smoothly for you.  My hair regrowth sounds likes yours . . good explanation!  Salt/pepper, sticks straight up like a baby chick, with too much scalp showing!  Gracie - good luck tomorrow! Ckk - hope you feel better quickly.  Tummy bug is the WORST!  Josie - welcome.  This is a fabulous group of ladies. . .a true gift to me. Momof3 - sorry you didn't get started today, but tomorrow is great!  They weren't sure if I would or not, but I did.  The personal exercise program sounds awesome! Hugs to you all (I could use them this evening)

Posts.Content: Dec 28, 2011 12:04PM Baileybump wrote: momof3 boys -- drink a LOT of water today.  My nurse told me to drink at least a gallon the day before and the day of chemo.  She gave me an A+ for hydration (I took my pole to the potty 3 times in about 3 hours!).  I drank Gatorade afterward, too. . . even when I wasn't thirsty.  Force it down. . . flush it out! April - welcome to you and your mom.  This discussion group has been a great resource to me and I hope you will find the same as you deal with your mother. cck -- I swear by my chiropractor.  He told me that 3 things take our spines out of alignment - - fatigue, injury, and chemical.  Chemo is the biggest chemical we can receive.  He wants to adjust me after each treatment (when I'm not sore).  I went last week, and it felt WONDERFUL.  As long as you feel okay, go for it! Heather - I'm so happy to hear that treatment #2 is DONE. . .woo hoo!  Praying that your SEs will be minimal, at most. Tomorrow will be treatment #2 for me, which means 3 weeks since I started.  Today, my crewcut pretty much came out completely in the shower.  Now I hope my head sensitivity/ache will subside. I'm definitely getting a copy of the Cancer Fighting Kitchen.  Thanks for the tip!

Posts.Content: Jan 28, 2012 01:36PM Baileybump wrote: Lisa - breastie sister hugs to you!  You bring excellent points. I think I try to hide the suckiest parts of this journey so people don't put on the sad boo boo face.  I want my life to be as "normal" as possible, so I try to minimize it to others.  I'm sure you "make it look easy" to others because you ARE strong, and you CAN do this.  That, and people don't want to think about their friend/loved one suffering.  Everyone around us is ready for this to be over. . . their lives aren't interrupted like ours.  Ours will never be the same.  People are always shocked that I'm not hanging over the toilet for days after chemo.  Everything thinks chemo makes you sick. . . because it used to.  I think that's another way you probably "make it look easy" . . . you're not sick.  But inside?  Nobody knows our inside thoughts, fears, anxieties, emotional states, except the wonderful ladies right here.  We get it. . . it sucks. . . all of it. Give 'em hell on Monday, girl. . . you can do it!

Posts.Content: Feb 10, 2012 07:59AM Baileybump wrote: My 4th and final treatment is DONE!  Woot woot!  The infusion went smoothly and my counts were all good (thank you, Lord!).  My labs were at 9:20 a.m. and we left at 1:30 - - usually it's after 2:00, so everything was clicking along today.  Because I had the phlebitis flare up on my hand last time, they gave me the infusion on the bottom of my arm - up from my wrist.  I'm pretty sure it's going to bruise (from the looks of it already).  I take off the day of treatment, the day after and Monday.  I found that Sunday/Monday are my "down days." I have a followup with surgeon next week (3 month check) and then radiation oncologist in early March.  They said I probably won't have to have any special scans/mammograms because of the radidation changing the "imaging".  He also said I will likely start the Tomoxifen after radiation, in case I have any side effects, they want to know what they are from and what to rule out. Hoping everyone else had a decent day "in the chair" (and you're right, it IS like an electric chair!).  We're on the way, girls!  Bead #4 is on the way!
Posts.Title: Taxotere/Cytoxan - December 2011 LeesaAnn AnnieLane

Rachel - love the new earrings!  You DO deserve to splurge on yourself.  Jewelry always makes me feel good, too.  :-) Heather - glad your appt is over, but sorry to hear about your OB.  It's so hard to find doctors with whom you are comfortable, and with the new slate of doctors we've all added, adding one more seems like a major bummer.  Can she recommend one to you? By the way, I still have Christmas decorations up, too.  Most are snowmen/winter decorations, but there's a renegade Santa and nutcracker on my mantel.  I figure the ground hog gave me 6 more weeks to get it all together.  ;-)

Posts.Content: Jan 19, 2012 04:38PM Baileybump wrote: Treatment #3 was smooth.  My labs were good.  I asked if I should be checked more often than the day of transfusion, but they said not since my counts were good.  Following treatment, my hubby and I went for a late lunch at Panera Bread.  When we were leaving Panera, a man followed us out and caught Joe's attention.  He asked if I was a cancer patient, and when I said, "yes," he said, "I want to give you a book that I just wrote."  The books is called, After Diagnosis: Life.  He said he was having lunch with his daughter and said, "I feel like I am SUPPOSED to give her a book."  God was clearing speaking to him through me. . . awesome and overwhelming.  It looks to be a wonderful book to work through.  He signed it for me and asked me to email him.  There are so many books I could read (and I'm not a reader), but for this man to feel like he was supposed to give me a book, I feel like it's a gift from God. . . WHAT A BLESSING (and exactly what I needed to pull myself out of this funk)!   The next few days will certainly be a challenge, but they seem to pass with the help of these forums.  Thanks for your positive thougths today. . . they worked!

I was reading an article today about "radation brain" being similar to chemobrain.  So for those of us having rads, too, we've got a double whammy on the brain issue!  My biggest problem is coming up with a word.  I know what I want to say, but sometimes get a block - frustrating!  And sometimes I read something, but it registers as something else.  I was at the drugstore today and saw BandAids for tough wounds.  I swear it said for TONGUE wounds . . . I had to take a closer look at it to see what in the world would qualify as a tongue wound.  My DH laughs at me, and thankfully I can laugh about it too.  I'm counting on it being temporary!

Posts.Content: Jun 21, 2012 02:20PM Baileybump wrote: Hello ladies!  I haven't been on here for quite some time.  I'm a heavy Facebook user and some of the ladies from the other BC group are on there.  If you ever want to connect on FB (Kathi Lipinsky), I'd love to do the same!  It's nice to catch up with all of you and see that you're doing well.  Kelly - if I'm calculating this right, you should be DONE with rads.  Celebrate!  Glad your skin held up well.  Mine did not.  I was blistered and oozing and just plain old miserable! I had a mammogram about 2 weeks ago (2 weeks post radiation).  It was supposed to be a 6-month post op check, but it was 7 months because of rads.  I was scared to death and it hurt so bad.  My breast tissue was still swollen from the rads.  I go back the end of September for my annual.  The technician said, "why don't you come in October?  We have lots of freebies then."  I said, "yeah, I know.  I was diagnosed in October and the freebies, commercials, events, etc. sucked pretty bad."  She laughed and said, "oh honey, stay as far away from here as possible. . . plan it for September 30th."  I'm certanly hopeful that this October will be much different. I decided I am officially going topless tomorrow.  I've been topless except for work, but so many of my co-workers know what's going on.  This wig is no longer me.  Time for Kathi to return!  I hope you are all having a nice summer. Cheers!

Posts.Content: Jun 27, 2012 11:47AM Baileybump wrote: Whata - yes, I do have some good hair growth.  It's coming in nice and thick. . . still very short, but also chemo curls (I'm just happy to have some hair)!  I've been working throughout treatment.  My employer is so supportive and wonderful.  I couldn't imagine NOT working through treatment. . . I needed my people!  There is another group of ladies on here - Taxotere/Cytoxan December - planning a get together in Willow Valley PA in July.  The women on this BO site are truly amazing!  I could have NEVER done this without all of your support! Kelly - I agree with Whatashocker and her posting about living life.  I truly believe that our minds will play tricks on us for the rest of our lives.  Hopefully the games will lessen as time goes on, but for now the wounds are fresh.  The smallest ting will set me off and I think, wow, it truly is still VERY close to the surface.  Some of the ladies in the other group had been posting information on PTSD as it relates to diseases.  I believe we all have some post traumatic stress in our lives from this diagnosis.  Markat - bummer about your period coming back!  I, too, haven't had one since December.  I'm 44 years old and am hoping it WON'T come back.  I've been taking Tamoxifen since May 29th and have pretty much SE-free.

Posts.Content: Dec 30, 2011 03:35PM Baileybump wrote: Momof3boys - congratulations on your first treatment completion. . . 25%!  Today I crossed the 50% mark.  Take the next few days "one day at a time."  I was still awake at 4:00 a.m. this morning (steroids hit me hard this time!).   I learned a lot today.  First, I can treat diarrhea at the first signs (I suffered for a few days after my first treatment, thinking I should allow it to leave my body).  They told me it will leave my body through my kidneys. . . flush your systems!  I have my Neulasta shot tomorrow and took a Clariton tonight.  My nurse said they have heard many positive things about Clariton, but they can't "recommend" it to patients.  She was happy to talk about it, though.  She also said to take Advil or Tylenol for any aches/pains/feverish feelings.  I was so afraid to take anything. . . she encouraged me to NOT suffer.  Fevers are different - report them in case of infection. Heatherweather - thank you for sharing!  I saved my hair. . . how would I go about making a halo?  that would be so cool to wear with some of my hats.  :-)  I, too, buzzed my hair at about day 10.  I couldn't stop thinking about it coming out, and decided to take it into my own hands, my own timing.  Yesterday (day 20), it ALL came out in the shower.  I was so thankful it was tiny little razor stubble, though.  I have a great wig that I wear to work. . . keeps my confidence level up. Rachel - enjoy your New Years Eve celebration. . . you'll be stunning on the dance floor.  :-) Good night all.

Posts.Content: Feb 18, 2012 11:20PM Baileybump wrote: The chemo brain you are all mentioning sounds exactly like what I've been experiencing, too.  Struggling to say the right word -- my DH laughs at some of my creative words.  At times I sound like my grandmother when she used to say three other names until she got to me.  LOL  I honestly didn't do too much reading on chemo brain because I was SURE it wasn't going to happen to me.  Duh. Josie - I think it's normal to be nervous.  We want to make sure we're doing what we can to beat this beast.  I think the folks having 6 treatments are doing a slightly different regimen.  Gracie - my 4th tx knocked me back a peg on the fatigue.  Today is 9 days post, and we ran some errands and did a little shopping today . . . and then I took a 2 hour nap.  It doesn't take much until I'm on the couch!  I guess since it was my last treatment, I think I'm done and over it. . . my body says different, though. Heather - hoping you had a great night out!  My first 3 infusions were in my hand (the 3rd one brought on some phlebitis), and my 4th was on the bottom of my arm, between wrist and elbow. Tonight, I started with phlebitis there, too.  Grrr.  It's all red and itchy.  Time for hydrocortisone and heat! We're doing something crazy and likely adopting another dog.  Our shepherds are 12 and 7.  We fell in love with a shepherd/retriever mix pup (in a Vermont rescue called Good Karma - - how could we refuse?).  My hubby had open heart surgery 7 years ago. . . 4 weeks later we added Yukon (our white shepherd).  So we're thinking I need a "recovery" dog, too.

HERSHEY, PA!  If any of you are amusement park enthusiasts, Hersheypark is adding another roller coaster.  I grew up at Hersheypark and rode everything and anything . . and now the speed/spinning makes me dizzy.  I can officially say, "back when I was a kid. . . "  Mom - I felt the same way about my 4th tx. . . and the people who asked what type of celebrating we were doing.  This week is my 3rd post-tx.  I'm having a hard time thinking I'm done.  I lived the past 12 weeks by "week one," "week two," etc.  The last tx definitely lasted longer (fatigue, especially), but mentally I was in a different place thanks to the "final" feeling.

Posts.Content: Mar 3, 2012 02:40PM Baileybump wrote: Robin - your sister's comment regarding "having hair" is one that we can all appreciate.  Add it to the list of stupid things people say! Annie - you have some re-growth!  Any sign of hair coming IN and not OUT is exciting!  Hoping the Lasix helps your eye issue. Wave - I hope you don't have an infection!  Though it's probably a good thing to hop onto antibiotics right away.  When I had phlebitis in my hand, the doctor wanted to look at it to make sure it wasn't a "chemo leak" because he said it can really irritate the skin.  I wonder if that's what happened? Leader Leesa - you'll have to educate us on the Tamoxifen.  I will start in 7-8 weeks when I'm done with radiation. I met with the RO today, but it was mostly informational.  Bedside manners is not his forte.  I don't care at this point. . . I just want to get on with it.  He said my treatments will be more difficult than average women because my breasts are so large (great).  He said I will be red, I will peel, I will be sore, and probably blister.  Can we say "how exciting"?  At this point of the journey, I'm pretty much numb.  I just want to get over it.  I go back on the 12th for the scan and then after they work out a treatment for my computer image, I will start (probably the following week).  So I will be about 6 weeks PFC.  Then after the rads, Tamoxifen.  He is estimating 36 treatments, but will know more later.  The first 28 will be full breast and the last will be concentrated to the tumor location.  No swimming during treatments, no sun in that area for 3 months after treatments.  So this girl will not be skinny dipping this year!  LOL - - never have. . . never will.

Momof3 - I'm jealous of your treatment facility!  Mine is brand new (less than a year old) and I don't have a coffee machine!  I have a few flat screen televisions and a jigsaw puzzle in the waiting room.  And your tx was lightening speed!  Mine is about 30 minutes because of the stupid "mask" they put on me.  Though it is snug and comfy. . .feels like a hug.    The therapists said, "and you get to take it home with you when you're done. . . and DRIVE YOUR CAR OVER IT!"  Amen! RACHEL - RACHEL - RACHEL!  We're all pulling you across the finish line, girl.  Whether you feel it or not, you have been a true inspiration to many of us.  You got this! Wave - you have the best stories!  I would wear the wig . . .your bald head seems like a "freak magnet."  LOL My 2nd and 3rd  rad tx went so much smoother than my first.  I just wasn't prepared for the emotions to fly that day.  Thank you all for your supportive words and encouragement.  It gives me such comfort in knowing that you have all felt the same way.   For those of you who have a few rads under your belt, when did you start to "feel" the effects?  I have had 3 so far.  After today's tx, "that side" felt rather warm.  And tonight when I was vacuuming, I felt a little discomfort on "that side."  Is it my imagination?  I'm anxiously awaiting how it's going to feel.  The unknown. . . so scary!

Posts.Content: Apr 13, 2012 08:21AM Baileybump wrote: So I wanted to share an emotional day again this week.  I made it through almost 2.5 weeks of radiation without having another meltdown.  I was already feeling reflective following Easter.  Yesterday, my radiation tech that I adore said "Kathi, you are such a positive in my day.  I literally look forward to your arrival" and a few other sweet things about sharing a similar faith.  As I was leaving, the two nurses said, "you look so nice, every day.  You're a class act."  Super sweet, right?  So I found myself crying off and on the whole way home, thinking about these wonderful medical professionals, you lovely ladies, my doctors, and everyone I met throughout this ordeal.  I find myself going through the motions, day in and day out, without stopping to be thankful for the gifts I have received along the way.  I was having one of those "what happened to me?" moments, followed by an overhelming humbled feeling.  The best part is trying to explain it to my DH.  "Why are you crying, sweetheart?"  I respond, "because people are nice to me" boo hoo hoo.  Bless his heart for dealing with me! Hugs to all.

Momof3 - I woke up last night with strong pressure in the middle of my back and sweaty (I'm 44 and pre-menopausal).  I blamed the Neulasta (seems like everyting gets blamed on it).  It passed in about a half hour, but scared me for sure!  It was like a knot in my chest (but radiating from my back). . . almost like I had to burp, but couldn't.  Or like a swallow was stuck.  Has anyone else felt this? Leesa - I concur with your outlook on surrounding yourself with positive thoughts.  We can do our best to fight this disease and to prevent a recurrance, but we need to live, too.  I know I will face trials and tribulations differently when this is over.  Who and what was once important at one time may no longer be.  And sometimes that includes relationships.  Some people who I "thought" would be there for me are completely absent.  I don't blame them. . . I blame me for having set expectations. BJMRN - my husband said the same thing to me last night. . . think about how far we've come since diagnosis.  Time goes quickly in the rearview mirror! Good luck to everyone having treatments this week.  Keep the positive energy flowing!

Posts.Content: Feb 5, 2012 02:19PM Baileybump wrote: I appreciate all of your posts on parabens and foods.  None of my docs have mentioned any of these items.  I have heard them before, but it's good to hear again.  I didn't know about the teflon pans, though.  Bummer!  My nurse oncologist recommended cast iron to help with "rebuilding." I haven't had any sensitivity to sound, but my eye lids twitch - both of them - off and on.  It's crazy.  I hate a twitchy eye, and I've had two of them for weeks! Regarding pankakes (sorry, I forget who posted it) - I have found that sweets I can taste.  I, too, ate waffles last weekend and they were like a delicacy!  For the week or two post chemo, I am always excited to have FLAVOR on my tongue!  I also enjoy pickles or pickled food -- I guess it's the vinegar.  And anything with a slight bit of pepper BURNS my tongue.  Very odd for me -- I have always been a hot/spicy gal.  I'm really hungry for hot wings. . . but will wait patiently for my tongue to recover.  No Superbowl parties here, but my hubby is a huge Giants fan, so we'll be enjoying the game at home. Annie - so sorry about your friend having to go home.  I surely hope you stay healthy! Rachel - loved your letter!

Posts.Content: Mar 25, 2012 12:45AM Baileybump wrote: I'm so thankful to have my power cord again so I can catch up on everyone!  I've been using my Nook to read, but it's so hard to post from the reader.  Today is a rainy day in Central PA.  Would have been a perfect day to stay in bed, but the new pup doesn't agree.  J  It's okay - - got up early, left DH in bed (he deserves it), drinking coffee and catching up with my lay-deeees!   Sorry this is so long-winded! A few of you talked about lashes and brows - - I didn't lose mine, either.  I guess the timing of the growth cycle worked in my favor.  My brows seemed to thin out a little, but nothing too noticeable. . . thankfully!  My hair is starting to come back in - - soft and gray!  Every day my DH says, "it's getting darker in the back."  I think he's just humoring me. The topic of support groups is interesting.  I honestly consider you my support group.  I, too, am blessed with a supportive DH, family, co-workers, and all of you.  One of my work friends, who had been through this a few years ago, said it took her about 2 years before she thought she needed to talk to someone.  When she was in the "midst of the fight" she didn't want to talk to women who were too far on the other side.  She wanted to focus on her own journey.  A few years later, when people seemed to have forgotten, she wanted to talk to others who understood.  She is thankful to join an ACS support group and meet other survivors, as well as offer support to newly diagnosed women.  I understand her way of thinking. I start my rads on Monday (hopefully).  I have to call on Monday morning to make sure they're ready for me.  I had to go back in this past week for them to make a mesh "shield" type of thing.  That will change the rad plan, but they were optimistic that they would be ready by Monday.  The mesh thing helps to pull my breast down, if that makes sense.  I am so sick of hearing "because your breast is large."  I'm a DD. . . have no other women my size EVER had to go through this?  Cut me a break, Doc.  Wave - your "backward" wig story was hysterical!  Thank you for sharing.  Your posts always bring a smile to my face. Jen - I am also 6 weeks PFC, and have aches and pains, especially in my knees.  My knees were always bad (genetic), but my goodness they crack and pop something fierce now.  Congrats on losing 30 pounds!  DH and I are going to focus on healthy choices and exercise, following this ordeal.  I'm using the excuse that the RO said not to fluctuate weight by 10 pounds (I need to lose so much more!), because of the treatments being so precise.  Would you share your supplement plan? Ckk - love the bike riding story.  In fact, it brought tears to my eyes.  Ride your bike and let the tears flow. . . and pedal away from them.  Thanks for the recommendation on the exercise book, too. Rachel - hope the pledges have rolled in.  How long is the fundraiser?  I like the suggestion of doing it on behalf of your pets.  I, too, have returned to biting my cuticles.  Ugh - habits!  I was fortunate to not have issues with my fingernails, and stayed away from the cuticles until I finished chemo and then like an old friend, I was back at them. Michelle - I hope you get some relief from the Lymphodema.  How sad that your MO didn't realize that's what it was.  Someone on here had suggested acupuncture.  I was going to try it for some of the neuropathy (I pre-purchased 2 visits), but haven't done it yet.  Maybe you should also give it a try? Lisa - You really have a bad bout of phlebitis for it to still be traveling.  Major bummer!  My two "brown" areas are getting lighter in appearance, but if I bump my hand, it hurts.  Heather - thanks for the recommendation on the deodorant.  I, too, am fruity smelling girl.  J  And I love supporting folks on Etsy.  Congrats on being halfway done! Karmil - wishing you the best for Monday!  We'll all be waiting to hear from you.  Do I sense a new laptop in your future?  ;-) Have a wonderful day, everyone!

Posts.Content: Mar 30, 2012 01:56PM Baileybump wrote: Rachel - so glad you're on this side of the last treatment.  Sorry it wasn't a great experience, but you made it to the other side!  Take it easy this weekend. . . listen to your body when it tells you to sleep. Karmil - go drive, girl! Leesa - sorry you are feeling like you do, but gosh it's easy to know why!  As ckk suggested. . . check out another MO if you're not completely satisfied.  We have the rest of our lives to live with this fear.  We need to be comfortable with the MO. I continue to be amazed at the various approaches the docs take to our treatment and survivorship.  My MO wants to do blood work when I'm done with rads and will then start me on Tamoxifen.  He said if we start Tamox and rads at the same time, there will be no way of knowing if I'm reacting to one or the other and waiting a few weeks won't make a difference.  I spoke to a girl in the waiting room the other day who started Tamox as soon as she had her surgery.  Perhaps the stage, grade, etc has something to do with it.  I don't know.  Oh. . . and we have the same MO!  He also said I would have annual mammograms (my BS wants me to have one in May for a 6-month check).  RO said that rads can give you false mammo readings, so no need to get worked up over something if you don't have to.  I'll be happy to have the mammo anyway.  My RO didn't do any blood tests.  In fact, he was bragging that "nothing I do here involves needles."  Well, the tattoos did (though he didn't do them, the rad therapist did).   I just wish there was one tried and true method of treating BC without every single person, treatment, follow-up being different.  I'd like to combine a little bit of each one of our experiences and mesh it together for the perfect treatment!  Today finishes one week (5 days) of rads.  So far, so good.  I dread the soreness in the coming days/weeks, but. . . TGIF!

Posts.Content: Apr 24, 2012 09:41PM Baileybump wrote: Hi ladies!  I haven't posted on her much lately, but I am more than mid-way through my rad treatments (22 done, 14 to go).  Today is the first day that I am sore under my breast.  My skin has been tolerating the treatments very well - - I consider myself very fortunate because I'm fair skinned.  The treatments go by quickly and hopefully you have a good group of people at the rad center.  You get to see them EVERY day, so you quickly form a bond with them.
